entry.title: The Unified Commerce Mandate: Leveraging SAP Technology to Achieve the 89% Retention Advantage
entry.content:
The era of multi-channel is over. Today's successful businesses rely on a connected SAP Intelligent Enterprise to eliminate friction and drive superior customer lifetime value (CLV).

 

Introduction: The Shift from Silo to System

The term "omni-channel" has long been synonymous with digital ambition, but its true significance has evolved. It is no longer a future-state strategy; it is a fundamental requirement of the Experience Economy. When a modern consumer engages with a brand, they expect a single, continuous conversation, regardless of whether the touchpoint is digital, physical, or voice.

This expectation is directly tied to business outcomes:

  • Customer Loyalty: Research indicates that enterprises with mature omni-channel engagement strategies achieve nearly 89% higher year-over-year customer retention rates compared to those with weak strategies. This loyalty directly translates to a 30% higher customer lifetime value (CLV).

  • Revenue Generation: Campaign performance also reflects this cohesion, with multi-channel campaigns resulting in a purchase rate increase of up to 287%. Furthermore, even traditional retail benefits, as digital omni-channel activity drives an approximate 80% increase in incremental visits to physical store locations.

The challenge, therefore, is structural: how do organisations consolidate disparate customer engagement systems and transactional data into one unified commerce platform?

The Solution Architecture: A Blueprint for Unified Commerce

Achieving this level of consistency requires a robust, scalable architecture that places the customer at the centre, integrating front-end engagement with back-end operations. This is the sweet spot of the SAP Intelligent Enterprise.

A. The Engagement Hub: SAP Commerce Cloud

SAP Commerce Cloud serves as the agile, API-first foundation for customer interaction. Its core strength is the ability to decouple the commerce engine from any single front-end presentation.

  • Headless Flexibility: This architecture allows businesses to quickly deploy commerce services to emerging channels (social, IoT, in-store screens) while ensuring that catalog, inventory, and pricing data remain consistent and centrally managed.

  • Fulfilment Optimisation: It is essential for enabling complex but critical omni-channel services such as Buy Online, Pick Up In-Store (BOPIS) and Ship-from-Store, which demand real-time synchronisation with logistics.

B. The Foundational Core: SAP Business Suite

Flawless omni-channel execution rests on accurate back-office data. SAP S/4HANA (the central pillar of the SAP Business Suite) provides the real-time, consolidated transactional system necessary for this execution.

  • By unifying financial, inventory, and supply chain data, S/4HANA guarantees that the inventory status shown to the customer on Commerce Cloud is instantly reflected across the enterprise, eliminating costly discrepancies and service failures.

C. The Integration & Extension Layer: SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)

The SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) is the critical middleware that eliminates data silos between the Commerce Cloud and the SAP S/4HANA core.

  • Integration Suite: Facilitates rapid, pre-built integration between SAP and non-SAP systems, ensuring a holistic flow of customer and order data.

  • Extensibility: BTP allows for the creation of custom applications (e.g., a bespoke in-store client for associates) that access unified data without disrupting the core business systems.

D. The Intelligence Engine: SAP AI Capabilities

To move beyond consistent service to truly contextual and predictive customer experiences, Artificial Intelligence (AI) is indispensable. SAP embeds AI across its portfolio:

  • SAP CX AI Toolkit: This powers personalisation through solutions like SAP Emarsys, enabling real-time product recommendations, personalised journeys, and optimised content based on unified customer data.

  • Intelligent Automation: SAP AI capabilities in the broader business suite enable predictive inventory management and automated demand forecasting, ensuring that the right product is in the right location to fulfil the promise made by the Commerce Cloud.

Conclusion

The mandate is clear: the market rewards unified, intelligent customer experiences. By leveraging SAP Commerce Cloud, SAP BTP, and the integrated power of SAP Business Suite and its AI capabilities, organisations can move beyond simply managing multiple channels to truly operating as an Intelligent Omni-Channel Enterprise, securing that vital customer loyalty and market growth.

entry.title: Secure By Default: SAP S/4HANA 2025 – The Security Journey Continues
entry.content:
What began as a bold initiative to strengthen the default security posture of SAP S/4HANA has, over the years, evolved into a core principle of the product. While the journey from concept to execution took time, we’ve now reached a point where Secure By Default is not just an aspiration - it’s a continuously expanding reality. With each release, more robust security settings are seamlessly integrated, helping customers benefit from enhanced protection without additional effort.

With the release of SAP S/4HANA 2025, also named SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025,  another step was taken by SAP S/4HANA supported by ABAP Platform to cover some additional topics for new installations, conversions, and system copies.

Identical to the former years, Secure By Default settings are applied for

    • SAP S/4HANA 2025 / SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025
    • All SAP products based on S/4HANA Foundation 2025

List of new Secure By Default Settings

In new installations, system copies, and conversions the following security relevant settings and configurations are applied automatically:

    • Add support for TLS1.3 for web-based interfaces of SAP S/4HANA in addition to TLS1.2
    • Adjust the security log of ICM to make it machine-readable for easier integration into SIEM solutions
    • Disable support for SAP logon tickets while still accepting SAP Assertion Tickets
    • Configure a Report-only Content Security Policy (CSP) for faster introduction of a Content Security Policy as second level of defence for S/4HANA
    • Disable the outdated ICM content scan interface as dedicated checks have been introduced in browser-based applications against Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and input validation.

Additional Information

As with SAP S/4HANA 1909, SAP S/4HANA 2020, SAP S/4HANA 2021, SAP S/4HANA 2023 customers will receive the security settings automatically with new installations, system copies and conversions. An opt-out is possible for the security relevant profile parameters but not recommended from SAP side. More details can be found in SAP Note 2926224.

As Secure By Default settings cannot and will not cover all aspects of security settings in S/4HANA systems, we highly recommend customers to perform additional reviews and improvements of their security settings. Good sources are the SAP security whitepapers. Secure by Default settings provide a good starting point, but there are additional security settings and configurations which are either customer specific, cannot be shipped as default or need to be applied on a regular basis (e.g., security patching).

    • Use the SAP-provided tools and services, such as Early Watch Alert, Configuration Validation and System Recommendations in order to display missing security patches. These inform you about gaps in a cost-efficient way.
    • Always introduce disruptive security settings with good timing. Conversion projects and new installations are opportunities to increase security. As a benefit, security testing can be included as part of the testing activities planned within the project. This leverages synergies in the area that has proven to be particularly costly.

Please refer to these blog posts for older SAP S/4HANA releases

    • For SAP S/4HANA 2023 – Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog https://blogs.sap.com/2023/10/18/another-chapter-of-secure-by-default-for-sap-s-4hana-2023/
    • For SAP S/4HANA 2022 – Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog https://blogs.sap.com/2022/11/03/secure-by-default-returns-with-sap-s-4hana-2022
    • For SAP S/4HANA 2021 – Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog The story resumes – Secure By Default for SAP S/4HANA 2021
    • For SAP S/4HANA 2020 – Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog Secure By Default for SAP S/4HANA 2020
    • For SAP S/4HANA 1909 – Secure By Default, please also refer to this blog Secure By Default: Ways To Harden Your Systems At (Almost) No Cost

Complete List of all SAP S/4HANA Secure By Default Settings

Below you can find a complete list of all Secure By Default settings that are included in SAP S/4HANA 2025. Bold entries were added with SAP S/4HANA 2025:

    • Security relevant profile parameters are set to secure values which increases security in areas such as:
        • Mandatory SSL Protection of session logon tickets (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • Disable support for SAP logon tickets while still accepting SAP Assertion Tickets (part of S/4HANA 2025)
        • Protect the RFC gateway against unauthorized RFC call forwarding (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • Strong password policies and password hashes (part of S/4HANA 2020)
        • Protection of internal system communication (part of S/4HANA 2020)
        • Strengthened authorizations system (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Enhanced RFC interface protection (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Enforce TLS1.2-only for web-based interfaces of SAP S/4HANA covering SAP Internet Communication Manager (ICM), SAP Start Service, SAP Host Agent (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • Add support for TLS1.3 for web-based interfaces of SAP S/4HANA in addition to TLS1.2 (part of S/4HANA 2025)
        • Disable the old insecure tickets for trusted / trusting communication (part of S/4HANA 2023)
        • Disable the outdated ICM content scan interface as dedicated checks have been introduced in the browser-based applications against Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and input validation (part of S/4HANA 2025)
    • Security relevant configurations and customizing are set to secure values
        • Prevent usage of non-reference user as reference user (part of S/4HANA 2022)
        • 3 parameters were changed to secure defaults in the Transport Management (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Web protection is increased by activation of the UCON HTTP allowlist (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Start authorizations for WebDynpro were enabled for an improved security for Webdynpro applications (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • All available scenarios of the Switchable Authorization Framework (SACF) are activated which adds additional functional authorization checks for technical function modules (part of S/4HANA 2020)
        • All available scenarios of the Generic Application Access Rules (SLDW) were activated as defined by SAP development (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Prevent the assignment of users to roles as part of transports to avoid that users get authorizations in higher tiers while importing transports (part of S/4HANA 2023)
    • Security relevant logging was enabled to support traceability and security monitoring
        • Performance, usability and analysis optimized log of RFC and SICF usage to support deactivation of unused RFC function modules and SICF services (part of S/4HANA 2022 and S/4HANA 2023)
        • Security Audit Log is activated what allows customers to trace critical activities in the system (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Activation of table logging for business-critical tables (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • HTTP server and HTTP client log of the SAP Internet Communication Manager is enabled (part of S/4HANA 1909)
        • Granular logging of Secure By Default activations in application log for easier debugging in conversions (part of S/4HANA 2023)
        • Adjust the security log of ICM to make it machine-readable for easier integration into SIEM solutions (part of S/4HANA 2025)
        • Configure a Report-only Content Security Policy (CSP) for faster introduction of a Content Security Policy as second level of defence for S/4HANA (part of S/4HANA 2025)
    • HANA for S/4HANA relevant configurations were enabled to improve traceability and encryption
        • SAP HANA Audit Log is switched on for HANAs running SAP S/4HANA. This enables traceability of activities on SAP HANA database level (part of S/4HANA 2021)
        • Leverage the automated activation of HANA Data at Rest Encryption Features as part of HANA2 SP07 installations to ensure that business data cannot be accessed on file system level (part of S/4HANA 2023)
    • Values of additional security relevant profile parameters were changed in the kernel default

entry.title: Standard Report for checking SoD Conflicts in SAP
entry.content:
Report for checking SoD Conflicts:
It is possible to use the standard report RSUSR008_009_NEW to set up a basic SoD analysis in
the SAP system (Figure 1). This below report is available from SAP_BASIS 740 to 758 ERP systems.
rsusr008_009_NEW

Figure 1: Report RSUSR008_009_NEW

 

With this report is it possible to get an overview of users/roles having access to critical
authorizations and/or critical combinations (SoD conflicts). By default this report comes with only one Critical Authorization variant 'SAP_RSUSR009' if you try to run this report with this default variant, then this report won't work as expected. 

Figure 2: Report RSUSR008_009_NEW Output

So, in order to get accurate results, you need to define the rule set first. The rule set contains critical authorizations and critical combinations. The critical authorizations must be defined. When this is done, you can define the critical combinations. 

Click on the 'New Entries' to create new Critical Authorization variant. This will trigger a Customizing TR and all the changes will be recorded under Cluster: VCUSRVAR

Now the custom Variant is created, but it's still missing the auth configuration or logics, which need to be added in the second folder named Authorization data.

Authorization Data folder only understands Auth ID. before proceeding further, you need to create a custom Auth ID.

Here is the process:

Now you need to make some changes in table USCRAUTHID. This is a standard table in SAP R/3 ERP systems.

 

By default, you can’t make or add any entries with SE16, SM30 transactions. You need to execute 1 function module to add entries to this table.

Go to Transaction: SE37

 

Now select Function Module: SE16N_INTERFACE

 

Now put the table name (USCRAUTHID) in the parameter ‘I_TAB’ and put ‘X’ in I_EDIT section and hit Execute.

 

After executing, you can add or modify entries to the table USCRAUTHID. Now click on Append Row option and fill all the details like Client number, Auth ID (Your preferred), Color and Auth ID description. And then save.

Now, once you created the Auth ID, you can proceed with Authorization Data folder. Double click on it and chose the newly created Auth ID.

Once you click continue the below screen will appear.

Click on the 'New Entries' and fill out the criteria. In the below example I have only added the T-code authorization logic. But one can add any type of standard or custom authorization objects available in the ERP system along with its Field Name and Value to get more accurate insight driven results and make the system more SoD Compliant. After filling out all the blanks & hit Save button,

After the critical authorizations are defined, the report can be run and the results (users/roles
having access to the defined critical authorizations) are shown on the screen.

Once you finish with all the above-mentioned steps, you need to go back to the Critical Authorization folder, where you have already created the custom variant. Select the variant and continue.

A blank screen will open. Click 'New Entries'

Now chose the Auth ID (which was created in table USCRAUTHID) from the search help area. Then save it. All the changes are recorded in a customizing TR. So, its better to use or track all the TR's generated while this activity.

Finally the Critical Authorization is ready for use. You can execute the report selecting the Critical Authorization by two way. You will get two selection criteria: User /Role. 

One can also merge multiple Critical Authorizations into Critical Combinations as per the business need.

 

Below are the technical Pre-requisites:

Whoever is defining or configuring this standard reports, should have access to below T-codes: 

  • SU_VCUSRVARCOM_DISP
  • SU_VCUSRVARCOM_CHAN
  • SU_VCUSRVAR_DISP
  • SU_VCUSRVAR_CHANGE

One can access this program by using T-code: SUIM

SUIM Path: - SUIM-> User -> With Critical Authorizations 

Below is the table structure and foreign key relationships of table USCRAUTHID

 

Thanks and regards,

Saikat Roy

RISE with SAP SAP S/4HANA #SoD

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Data Migration Using Parallel Processing in CDS View.
entry.content:
Introduction:

Migrating data is a key part of moving to SAP S/4HANA. When dealing with large datasets from older systems, it's important to migrate them effectively. In this blog, we'll look at how to leverage Parallel Processing in CDS Views to enhance the data migration process.

Business Scenario: 

We're moving sales orders from an old system into the target table [zsodet_target].  We pull the data using a CDS view [ ZSALESDATA_MIGRATION_USINGPP] and handle it with AMDP logic. To speed things up, we break the migration into date ranges and run them in parallel using destination groups.

Steps for Implementation: 

1. Create Source and Target Tables: 

a.  Source Table: ZSODET_LEGACY(Sales Data Source Table).

Entries of legacy table.

 

b. Target Table: ZSODET_TARGET(Sales data target table) - Initially it doesn't have any record, the data will be migrated from legacy table. 

 

2.  Create a CDS View:  The CDS view "ZSALESDATA_MIGRATION_USINGPP" is designed to access old sales data in a modular, secure, and efficient manner — particularly when filtered by date ranges — prior to its migration to the S/4HANA system.

Purpose of the CDS View

Feature Purpose
EncapsulationEncapsulates the logic to read only relevant legacy data (e.g., only for given date ranges)ReusabilityMakes the selection logic reusable across AMDP methods, reports, and moreSecurity & ReadabilityCDS views are clearer, safer, and easier to optimize than raw SELECT statementsIntegration with AMDPAMDP can easily consume CDS entities for fast, pushdown-enabled data processing in HANA

 

 

Parallel Processing Logic:

 To achieve parallel processing, we will use AMDP (ABAP Managed Database Procedures) along with the above CDS view for high performance and complex data processing directly in HANA — instead of slow ABAP logic. It runs entirely on the HANA DB, not in ABAP layer — so it's much faster.

AMDP:

3. Create Remote-Enabled FM:   Wraps AMDP method in a RFC-enabled FM for remote execution.

4.  Create Server Group (RFC Destination Group):

Purpose:  Server groups allow ABAP programs to run function modules in parallel across multiple application servers using CALL FUNCTION->STARTING NEW TASK -> DESTINATION IN GROUP.

Steps for creating server group:

  •  Go to Transaction: RZ12
  • Click on create assignment
  • Give the server group and instance name
  • Give the properties of the instance and click on Copy.
  • Server group will be created and check the server group status.
  • Distribute workload (for parallel execution)

5. Purpose of the Report Program

  • Dividing the Data: It breaks down the entire dataset (like sales orders) into smaller, more manageable pieces based on date ranges that the user can set. Starting Parallel Tasks: For every piece, the report kicks off a remote-enabled function module using STARTING NEW TASK, which lets multiple tasks run at the same time, greatly boosting performance.

  • Monitoring Tasks and Handling Completion: It keeps an eye on each parallel task and makes sure everything is in sync by waiting for all tasks to finish before wrapping up the process.

  • Enhanced Efficiency and Runtime: By using parallel processing, the report cuts down the total migration time and makes better use of system resources.

    • Status Output
      Once all chunks are processed, the report provides confirmation that the data migration has been successfully completed.

     

     

  • Now, check the target table to see the migrated data from legacy table.

    Thanks.

entry.title: HANA Tenant Copy fails with error Data receive failed.Specified network name is no longer available
entry.content:
Hi All,

Greetings ! I hope you all are doing well ! 

I recently faced a severe issue while performing  Homogeneous Migration using HANA tenant Copy method. This issue occurred because of a small patch version bug. Kindly find the details of issue below.

Issue : 

During Homogeneous Migration using HANA Tenant Copy, the finalization step failed with the command:

ALTER DATABASE <TARGET SID> FINALIZE REPLICA

While executing the finalization of replica using command "ALTER DATABASE <TARGET SID> FINALIZE REPLICA", It ran for 8–10 minutes and then threw the error:

Could not execute 'ALTER DATABASE <SID> FINALIZE REPLICA' in 7:18.813 minutes.
Data receive failed. java.io.IOException: The specified network name is no longer available: 147.204.180.42:49173 -> <DBhost>:30213
System:<SID>SYSTEMDB TenantName:(none) SiteVolumeID:0:1 SiteType:NONE ConnectionID:107701 SessionID:602860719722796

Impact:

  • Finalization failed.
  • Entire target database (SYSTEMDB + tenant DB) went down.
  • After manual restart (HDB start), SYSTEMDB came up, but tenant DB did not.

This error not only fails the finalization but also brings down your entire target Database (SYSTEMDB + tenant DB), upon starting the DB manually using HDB start, System DB comes up but tenant doesn't.

Initial Observations

  • Error suggested network I/O failure.

By looking at the error, it seemed out to be a network I/O error and also when we checked the HANA traces, we found a file named "ios failure.txt" was generated and there was below error inside the file

  • HANA trace showed file ios failure.txt with:
exception throw location:
0: 0x00007f248e48a1aa in ltt::throw_ios_failure(...) at ltt/base/impl/ios.cpp:27
1: 0x00007f248e48e269 in ltt::getline(...) at ltt/ios.hpp:594

This shows, there is issue with either server disk or network throughput, We thought of re-triggering the replication and tried again to finalize but same issue occured. Upon deep, analysis of the logs especially the inder server logs of tenant DB, we found below error.

Tenant DB logs revealed:

2025-11-15 04:48:53.611294 f PersistenceLayer PersistenceController.cpp(00779) : persistence startup failed with ptime exception:
ERROR [SQL-3] fatal error: A downward catalog migration from 445 to 441 is not supported.

Our case:

 

  • Source HANA version: 2.0 Rev 79.05
  • Target HANA version: 2.0 Rev 83.00

 

Cause:

The error occurred because catalog migration was not compatible between these revisions. We found the following SAP note for the above issue but this note says the upgrade path for HANA not for tenant copy however after confirmation from Product team, this was confirmed that this note is applicable for tenant copy as well. We must follow this note before starting the tenant copy to compare source and target HANA version whether tenant copy is feasible or not. Having said that, in tenant copy, target must be higher than or equal to source, but this is not true, there are few exceptional cases which can be analyzed using below note. The case applied for the upgrade , same is applied for HANA tenant copy.

https://me.sap.com/notes/1948334

Resolution:

Here we had two options to resolve this compatibility issue during tenant copy as per this note.

  1. Upgrade Source from Rev 79.05 → Rev 82.00
    (Major change, higher impact)

  2. Upgrade Target from Rev 83.00 → Rev 87.00
    (Minor change, safer option)

It is recommend to go with the second option,because it involves only a minor revision change and is less disruptive.

If you are at critical stage of your activity, second option is preferrable. 

✅Best Practice:
Always validate source and target revision compatibility using SAP Note 1948334 before starting tenant copy.

Thanks & Regards,
Aakarsh Raghuvanshi
SAP

entry.title: SAP HANA Tenant Copy Fails at FINALIZE REPLICA with 'Write rootkey data failed' error
entry.content:
Hi All,

Greetings ! Hope you all are doing well !

Issue:

When you finalize the copy procedure on the target system by SQL command

ALTER DATABASE <target_database_name> FINALIZE REPLICA

the sql command fails with the error:

Could not execute 'ALTER DATABASE <TARGET SID> FINALIZE REPLICA' in 1:36.403 minutes . 
SAP DBTech JDBC: [2]: general error: nameserver failed to process the request;ltt exception: exception 7100010: Database replication error: Write rootkey data failed: Check tenant indexserver trace for details.

Within the nameserver trace of the target system you see an error like:

nameserver_reque TREXNameServer.cpp(01174) : ltt exception: exception 1: no.7100010 (MultiDB/impl/DatabaseReplicationManagerImpl.cpp:666) TID: 90034
Database replication error: Write rootkey data failed: Check tenant indexserver trace for details.

Upon checking the error logs, we found below error logs

2799342]{-1}[-1/-1] 2025-07-22 05:15:30.245186 w PersistenceManag DisasterRecoveryProtocol.cpp(02268) :  secondary version=2.00.083.00.1740646891 higher than primary version=2.00.072.00.1690304772
[2799342]{-1}[-1/-1] 2025-07-22 05:15:30.265857 w sr_dataaccess    DisasterRecoveryProtocol.cpp(03696) : Data compatibility check with primary failed, not compatible ..

Cause:

This is a bug in SAP HANA program itself, there is an incompatibility between the serialization of TrexNet::Response in source system and its deserialization in target system.

Affected Releases: SAP HANA 2: Revisions <= 075.00 (SPS07)

Release:

In our case, source was at HANA 2.0 rev 72.00 and target was HANA 2.0 rev 83.00 so this issue occured.

Resolution:

Although there was a workaround, here is what we observed:
When we performed the consistency checks on tables, row views, procedures, and functions, all counts matched exactly with the source system. However, when running the command SELECT * FROM M_DATABASES, the tenant status showed FINALIZE REPLICA ERROR. This issue got resolved after restarting the database, but this approach is not recommended, as it may lead to root key issues when taking the first backup after migration.

According to SAP Note 3524790, this bug exists in HANA 2.0 revisions ≤ 75.00 and has been fixed starting from HANA 2.0 revision ≥ 76.00.

Solution Applied

We upgraded the source system to HANA 2.0 revision 79.02, which successfully resolved the issue. After the upgrade, we were able to proceed with replica finalization and takeover without any further problems.

Important Point

Even though SAP Note 3524790 states that upgrading the source to any version ≥ 76.00 should solve the issue, in reality, not every revision works. There are patch-level problems as well that can cause replica finalization to fail. I have covered this additional issue in a separate blog, which you can refer to for more details HANA Tenant Copy fails with error Data receive failed.Specified network name is no longer available .

Recommendation

For now, please refer to the SAP Note below for validating source and target compatibility before planning a HANA tenant copy. This note is strongly recommended even if your source is already above revision 75.

SAP Note: https://me.sap.com/notes/1948334

 

Thanks & Regards,

Aakarsh

SAP

entry.title: Simple understanding of Hierarchies in SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics– Part 1 (Basics)
entry.content:
Accurate CDS hierarchy modeling and understanding is critical for financial reporting and operational analytics. Without well-defined hierarchies, drill-down analysis and aggregated insights become challenging. This blog demystifies hierarchy concepts in SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics and shows how they power SAC,Multidimensiona Reports , AFO and Datasphere scenarios.This blog will give you the basic understanding of Hierarchies in CDS Views (S4 Hana)

What This Blog Covers

  • Common hierarchy terminologies
  • Types of hierarchies in CDS Views
  • Standard hierarchies in S/4HANA
  • Why custom hierarchies matter


1. Key Terminologies-

Before diving into implementation, let’s clarify the basics:

  • Root Node : Top-most node in the hierarchy. Has No parent. Signifies the Hierarchy Structure and contains the Hierarchy metadata. A hierarchy can have several root nodes.
  • Hierarchy Node : Represents a group or element in the hierarchy.
  • Parent Node : A node that has child nodes beneath it.
  • Child Node : Belongs to a parent node.
  • Leaf Node : Lowest node in the hierarchy (end point).
  • Hierarchy Directory : Stores hierarchy definitions.
  • Siblings : Nodes sharing the same parent.
  • Hierarchy Level : Indicates depth of a node in the hierarchy. Levels can be defined as 0,1,2,3 . In S/4 EA change level based hierarchies to Parent child hierarchies .
  • Recursive Hierarchy: Nodes can reference themselves (e.g., Org Structure). Implemented using self-association in CDS.
  • Hierarchy Node Texts: These contain the descriptive names or labels associated with the hierarchy nodes, typically derived from the related master data (for example, the name or description of a General Ledger account or Product Hierarchy Description).
  • Orphan nodes, These are the nodes missing a link to a root. You can choose to ignore them, raise an error, or promote them as alternative roots using annotations like ORPHANS = ROOT

2. Example of a Hierarchy-

Company → Product Category → Product → Variant Shoe Model 1

Example:

  • Company (ABC Corp)  → Root Node -> The top most node in hierarchy (Defined via Hierarchy Directory and Root node has no parent defined)---- To be discussed in details in another Part 2.
  • Product Category (Footwear)  → Child of Company->A Parent Node for Product but this is not the Root node(Since it has Company as a Parent Node).
  • Product (Shoes)  → Child of Product Category->Parent Node for Variant
  • Variant (Shoe Model 1)  → Leaf Node->Lowest Node in the hierarchy

 In SAP: For Cost Center or Profit Center hierarchy, Controlling Area could be the root node.

3. Types of Hierarchies in CDS Views-

In S/4HANA Embedded Analytics, hierarchies are modeled using CDS annotations. Most common type:

  • Parent-Child Hierarchy 🔗 Always recursive. Each node references its parent, forming a tree structure. Example: Cost Center hierarchy where each cost center belongs to a higher-level.

 

  • Level-Based Hierarchy 🔗Not supported in S4 Hana Embedded analytics as Analytical engine supports only Parent Child Hierarchy for drill downs and aggregations.

CDS Annotation Example:

@Hierarchy.parentChild:
{ recurse:          {   parent: 'ParentNode',   child:  'HierarchyNode'   },
  siblingsOrder:    {   by: 'SequenceNumber',    direction: 'ASC'   },
  directory:        '_Hierarchy' }

4. Standard Hierarchies in S/4HANA-

SAP delivers several predefined hierarchies:

  • Cost Center Hierarchy – For controlling and cost reporting
  • Profit Center Hierarchy – For profitability analysis
  • GL Account Hierarchy – For financial statements
  • Product Hierarchy – For material classification
  • EHS Location Hierarchies – For Environment, Health & Safety compliance

5. Custom Hierarchies-

Business requirements often demand custom hierarchies:

  • Example: A sales region hierarchy combining geography and product lines.
  • Implemented using CDS Views by developing a relation between Dimension Views and Hierarchy View.

6. Why Hierarchies Matter?

  • Enable drill-down reporting in SAC or Fiori Multidimensional Reports/AFO.
  • Support aggregations at multiple levels
  • Provide flexibility for planning and analytics

7. Technical Details: Where Hierarchies Are Stored-

  • HRRP_NODE_N Table: Stores Parent Node info, hierarchy node level details, and relationships between nodes(Example where GL Account/Profit Center/Cost Center Hierarchy details are stored).
  • HRRP_DIR_N Table: Stores Hierarchy Directory info (name, version, metadata).

👉When you activate or create a hierarchy (standard or custom), these tables are updated.

  • HRRP_NODE_N = Node-level details (Parent-Child relationships)
  • HRRP_DIR_N = Directory-level details (Hierarchy header info)

8. Hierarchy Components & Annotations-

  • A well-defined hierarchy in CDS has multiple views:

Source(Master Data) View: Provides key fields and relationships (Eg GL Account/Cost Center/Product related details).
Hierarchy View: Contains the relationships and parent–child links. Eg - Hierarchy(Child) Node, Parent Node, Node levels etc.
Directory View: Provides metadata about hierarchy variants -- Optional.
Text Views for labeling nodes and directory entries . Eg: GL account and it's text/ Cost center and it's text etc.

Proper annotations (@Hierarchy.parentChild, @ObjectModel.dataCategory: #HIERARCHY) control recursion, sibling order, orphan handling, and directory association

Notes:

  • Parent–Child Hierarchy: Supported in CDS for analytics; recursive structure.
  • Level-Based Hierarchy: Not supported in CDS for analytical consumption (only parent–child works for drill-down).
  • Orphan nodes = Nodes without a parent.
  • A Parent Node can have multiple Hierarchy Nodes/Child nodes but a hierarchy node cannot have multiple parents
  • A node can appear under different parents in different hierarchy versions, not in the same hierarchy( It usually refers to alternate hierarchy versions or variants, not simultaneous parents in the same hierarchy. For example:

Hierarchy Variant/Version 1: Region → Country → City

Hierarchy Variant/Version 2: Sales Channel → Country → City.This is managed via Hierarchy Directory.

  • A CDS hierarchy cannot serve as the underlying source for building another CDS hierarchy.

Next Article (Part 2)

  • How to activate Standard hierarchies and develop Custom Hierarchies in CDS Views (S4 Hana EA).
  • How to consume hierarchies in SAC

entry.title: Restoring Transport Routes After System Refresh – Edit Option Disabled in STMS
entry.content:
Hi Folks,

Greetings! I hope you are all doing well.

During a recent System Refresh activity, I encountered an issue where the Transport Route configuration could not be edited in the Quality system after restoring a backup from the Production system. Since this issue can occur frequently during refresh cycles, I am sharing the root cause, analysis, and step-by-step resolution.

Issue Summary: -

After performing a backup restore from Production to Quality, we executed the standard post-refresh activities—one of which includes clearing the existing TMS configuration in the target (Quality) system.

However, once the system came up and I launched STMS, the Edit / Change icon was disabled, preventing me from defining or modifying the transport routes.

 

 

Because the Quality system was refreshed from Production, the original routes and controller information were overwritten or removed—leading to a mismatch between the local TMS configuration and the domain controller.

Root Cause:-

During the system refresh:

  • Transport Management System (TMS) data from Production overwrote the Quality system’s configuration.
  • As part of cleanup, TMS routes were deleted or became inconsistent.
  • The system lost its connection to the Domain Controller, causing the edit icon in STMS Transport Routes to become unavailable.

Essentially, the Quality system was no longer recognized as part of the transport domain.

Technical Explanation: -

After the refresh:

  • The refreshed system contains production TMSADM keys, not matching the domain controller.
  • Therefore, the system cannot authenticate with the domain controller.
  • As a result, STMS → Transport Routes goes into read-only mode.

To synchronize the system again, we must update the local TMS config with the domain controller.

Solution – Restore TMS Route Using “Adjust with Controller: -

Perform the steps in the Quality system:

Step 1: Log in with DDIC user in client 000

This is mandatory because TMS configuration changes can only be done in:

  • Client 000
  • With DDIC or TMSADM authorized users

Step 2: Execute Transaction STMS

The system will try to connect to the domain controller.

STMS T-code

Step 3: Navigate to Transport Routes

Step 4: Adjust Configuration with Domain Controller

Go to: Configuration>Adjust with controller

You will notice the Edit icon is disabled.

Then click on configuration and get option is adjust with controller just see below snap.

 

Click Yes when prompted.

This action forces the Quality system to:

  • Re-import TMS configuration from the Domain Controller
  • Regenerate TMSADM RFC connection
  • Restore the correct system role (Dev → QA → Prod)
  • Load the existing route definitions

Step 5: Save the Transport Route

  • After synchronization, the correct routes appear automatically.
  • Click Save to activate the configuration.

Additional Technical Checks (Optional but Recommended)

  1. Verify RFC connection of TMSADM

         SM59 → ABAP Connections → TMSADM_<SID>_XXX

         Status should be green.

  1. Check Domain Controller system

         In Domain Controller (usually DEV system):
         STMS → Overview → Systems

          Ensure the refreshed system is visible and status is Active.

  1. Check consistency

       Run:

       STMS → System Overview → Extras → Verify Configuration

Conclusion

After a system refresh, you may find the Edit option disabled in STMS due to mismatched TMS configuration. Using “Adjust with Controller” is the correct approach to synchronize the system with the transport domain controller and restore the predefined routes.

This process ensures that:

  • Quality system aligns with the domain controller
  • Routes are restored without manual reconstruction
  • TMS remains consistent and operational

 

Thanks for Reading!

Please feel free to share your thoughts, improvements, or any similar experiences you’ve encountered during system refreshes.

Regards,

Nishant Garg

Source Data : TABLE

JSON_STRING

IDJSON_STRING

2[{"code":"MI007","descr":"James Bond"},{"code":"MI005","descr":"Max Well"}]
3[{"code":"MI007","descr":"James Bond"},{"code":"MI005","descr":"Max Well"},{"code":"MI004","descr":"Donald Trump"}]

ID 2 and 3 have multiple code and descr 

In order to split/ extract the Json string in such a way that,

The code and descr should be splitted/extracted for same ID's which results in multiple rows.

 

FUNCTION "XYZ_JSON" ( ) 

RETURNS TABLE (ID NVARCHAR(50),
               CODE_VALUE NVARCHAR(255),
               TEXT_VALUE NVARCHAR(255)
		       )

LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
SQL SECURITY DEFINER AS
BEGIN

 -- Create a temporary table to store the final results

 DECLARE result_table TABLE ( 
                   ID NVARCHAR(50),
                   CODE_VALUE NVARCHAR(255),
                   TEXT_VALUE NVARCHAR(255)
				   );

 -- Declare working variables

 DECLARE current_row_id INT; -- Holds the row ID for the current row

 DECLARE remaining_string NVARCHAR(5000); -- Holds the remaining string to process

 DECLARE code_match NVARCHAR(255); -- Stores the currently matched value

 DECLARE descr_match NVARCHAR(255);

 DECLARE i INT; -- Match occurrence counter

 DECLARE cursor input_sql for SELECT ID,JSON_STRING, OCCURRENCES_REGEXPR('code":"' IN "JSON_STRING" ) as occur_code
 FROM "TABLE/CAL.VIEW";

 -- Loop through each row of the input table

  FOR cur_row AS input_sql

     -- Replace this with your actual table name

     DO

     -- Initialize variables for processing the current row

      current_row_id := :cur_row.id; -- Current row ID

      remaining_string := :cur_row.json_string; -- Current row's string to process

      IF cur_row.occur_code = 0 OR cur_row.occur_code IS NULL THEN

           INSERT INTO :result_table VALUES (cur_row.id, cur_row.json_string, NULL);

      END IF;



        FOR i IN 1..cur_row.occur_code DO


           code_match := SUBSTRING_REGEXPR('code":"([^"]*)"' IN remaining_string OCCURRENCE i GROUP 1);

           descr_match := SUBSTRING_REGEXPR('descr":"([^"]*)"' IN remaining_string OCCURRENCE i GROUP 1);

          -- Check if a match is found


           IF code_match IS NOT NULL THEN

                -- Add the match to the result table

                INSERT INTO :result_table VALUES (current_row_id, code_match, descr_match);

              ELSE

                -- Exit the loop when no more matches are found

                 BREAK;

           END IF;

        END FOR;

   END FOR;

    -- Output the final results

 return SELECT * FROM :result_table;

END;

entry.title: Implementing reliable versioning in SAP HANA using SQL triggers
entry.content:
Recently I worked on data versioning and thought it could be interesting for someone else 😊Whether you are tracking configuration changes, business rules, pricing tables, or workflow definitions, versioning ensures that updates are auditable, deterministic, and consistent. 

In this post, I'm going to share my thoughts how to implement versioning with statement-level triggers, solve typical challenges, and ensure version increments occur exactly once per relevant change.

I implemented versioning at the database level using SQL triggers, ensuring changes are tracked automatically and consistently. In this blog post I’m going to simplify the business versioning logic, so we can concentrate as only on the technical part. Furthermore I used HANA system versioning tables, but it is out of the scope in this post. Please be aware that this is just a small part of the real use case.

Use Case Overview

Imagine we have two tables:

  1. Entity A: Stores entity A metadata including its version. Each A_id column has a “version” column.
  2. Entity B: Stores entity B entries that reference a A_id. 

Whenever new rows are inserted into the table B, the corresponding entity A’s version must be incremented. This ensures that any change in usage of a rule automatically updates its version. 

Requirements

  • Insert/Update N rows into Entity B with the same A_id at once → entity A version increments once, not N times.
  • Insert rows into Entity B with different A_ids → each entity A version should increment once.

I implemented a statement-level trigger combined with temporary transaction-scoped tables.

Table Setup

CREATE TABLE "A" (
a_id NVARCHAR(10),
version INT
);
CREATE TABLE "B" (
b_id NVARCHAR(10),
a_id NVARCHAR(10),
description NVARCHAR(100)
);

To ensure that versions will be incremented once per transaction, two help tables are needed. We are going to track which a_ids have already been processed using:

CREATE GLOBAL TEMPORARY TABLE TMP_A_PROCESSED (
a_id NVARCHAR(10)
) ON COMMIT DELETE ROWS;

CREATE TABLE TMP_A_NEW (
a_id NVARCHAR(10)
);

The first table remembers which a_ids have already been incremented in the current transaction. The second table collects a_ids inserted by the current statement. 

Next we will need a versioning trigger. 

CREATE TRIGGER UPDATE_VERSION
AFTER INSERT OR UPDATE
ON B
REFERENCING NEW TABLE NEW_ROWS 
FOR EACH STATEMENT
BEGIN
INSERT INTO TMP_A_NEW (SELECT DISTINCT a_id FROM :new_rows
WHERE a_id NOT IN (SELECT DISTINCT a_id FROM TMP_A_PROCESSED));
UPDATE A t
SET "VERSION" = "VERISON" + 1
WHERE t.a_id IN (SELECT a_id FROM TMP_A_NEW);
INSERT INTO TMP_A_PROCESSED (SELECT DISTINCT a_id FROM TMP_A_NEW);
DELETE FROM TMP_A_NEW;
END;

Do not forget to turn off autocommit or wrap your inserts/updates in a procedure! TMP_A_NEW table can be defined as a global temporary table too. It is even better, so you will avoid data deletion inside a trigger.

This example can be extended by adding more tables where the versions will be increased in a chain. 

Conclusion

Implementing versioning logic using SAP HANA SQL triggers offers a robust and automatic way to ensure data consistency across related tables.

The provided example should be considered only as my personal experience.

entry.title: The Secure Way to Migrate S/4HANA: Step-by-Step HANA Tenant Copy with SSL Encryption
entry.content:
As customers rapidly migrate S/4HANA systems to Private Cloud environments (Azure, AWS, GCP, SAP RISE), they often choose an "as-is" migration. This decouples functional upgrades from the technical move, significantly compressing project duration and minimizing the need for extensive regression testing.

While traditional methods like HANA Backup/Restore (only viable for small databases) and HANA System Replication (HSR) are common, HSR presents critical challenges in a cloud migration:

  1. Homogeneous Naming: HSR demands the same SID and Instance Number for source and target, which conflicts with new naming conventions often required on the cloud, especially in SAP RISE.
  2. Auxiliary Usage: Using the HA/DR focused HSR solution for a one-time copy complicates the reconfiguration of the target HA/DR setup after cutover.
  3. Cutover Time: Breaking replication and re-establishing HA/DR post-cutover adds additional downtime.

HANA Tenant Copy: The Migration Alternative

HANA Tenant Copy is an ECS-supported approach that addresses these HSR limitations. While operationally somewhat to HSR, it differs conceptually and is suitable for migrating systems that require a SID change on the target. It creates an isolated replica of any tenant, requiring mostly that the target HANA version is same or higher than the source.

🔐Securing the Tenant Copy Data Transfer (SSL)

A crucial security requirement is ensuring the data transfer between source and target is secure via SSL. Most Basis teams overlook this, thinking it requires external certificates. However, we can easily achieve this using the inbuilt certificate every HANA DB already possesses. In this post, we are going to see how we can 

Pre-Requisite –

Set-up below parameters on Source and Target Database. Also, log mode should be normal for Tenant Copy to work.

Verify the SYSTEM layer values of the following parameters in the global.ini file:

  • [communication] ssl must be set to systempki
  • [system_replication_communication] enable_ssl must be set to on

On Source DB only –

Verify the SYSTEM layer values of the following parameters in the global.ini file:

  • [communication] listeninterface must be set to .global

(A DB restart would be required in most cases).

When establishing connectivity between the Source and Target databases, the following port ranges should be opened. If security policies are restrictive, specific ports based on the instance number can be opened instead.

Port Range

Purpose

3XXXX

Mandatory. SQL port of the HANA Index Server. Main port used by application servers and SQL clients to connect to the HANA DB.

4XXXX

Mandatory. Internal HANA communication port, used heavily for system replication (HSR) and Tenant Copy.

5XXXX

Recommended. Used by nameserver, web dispatcher–related connections, and certain internal HA/scale-out services. Helps hosts exchange availability and topology information.

 Step-by-Step Secure Tenant Copy Execution

Step1: Create a dummy Tenant Database (ABC) on the source system to serve as a copy template. (Note: For actual migration, use the existing S/4HANA connected database, skipping this creation step.)

Take backup of the source database so that Tenant copy can be initiated (same restriction as that of HSR)

Step 2: On the target HANA system, create a Personal Security Environment (PSE) (e.g., TenantCopy) and assign its purpose as Database Replication.

Step 3: On the source HANA system, navigate to the $SECUDIR directory and copy the content of the root certificate, which is typically named clientpki_SYSTEMDB.cer. (Important: Use the SYSTEMDB certificate, not the tenant's certificate like clientpki_ABC.cer).

Step 4: Using the copied certificate content, create a new certificate entity within the target HANA database.

Step 5 : On the target system, execute the necessary SQL query to identify and note the certificate number assigned to the new certificate created in Step 4.

Step 6 : Add the certificate identified in Step 5 to the PSE created in Step 2 on the target system.

Step 7: Verify the successful addition by querying the PSE_CERTIFICATE view on the target HANA system.

Step 8: On the target system, create a Credential for the source database, using the Source SYSTEMDB password for authentication.

Step 9: On the Target, initiate the Replica Query to copy the source tenant (ABC) to the target tenant (XYZ). (In a real scenario, you would first stop the target Application Server, drop the existing S/4HANA target DB, and then create the new tenant with the exact required target name.).

Step 10 : Monitor the replication from the Target. Replication is active when the status shows Target_Active_Status = “Yes”. The replication is complete when the DB status in M_DATABASE changes to ACTIVE REPLICA, indicating the target is ready for finalization.

 

Step 11: On the target system, issue the Finalize Replica Query to bring the target database online. (Crucially, before executing the finalization, stop the source S/4HANA system to mark the business downtime start.)

After finalization, perform follow-up activities, including reconfiguring the HDBUSERSTORE and starting the target S/4HANA application system.

References –

Copying and Moving Tenant Databases | SAP Help Portal

Copy or Move Tenants Within System Replication | SAP Help Portal

 

Best Regards,

Javed Alam

SAP BASIS Technical Architect

entry.title: End-to-End AMDP Exception Handling: From HANA Development in ADT to ABAP Report Execution
entry.content:
1. Introduction 

 In modern SAP applications, performance-critical logic is increasingly pushed down to SAP HANA using AMDP (ABAP Managed Database Procedures). 
While AMDPs offer high performance and seamless interaction with HANA SQL Script, developers often struggle with exception handling, especially when integrating AMDP logic with CDS views and ABAP reports. This blog explains how to design an AMDP method with proper exceptions, how to consume it from ABAP, and which scenarios require CDS table functions. 
By the end, you will have a clear understanding of how to manage AMDP exceptions in real-world projects. 

2. Business Requirement 

A business user wants to extract sales order header (VBAK) data based on flexible filter conditions. 
The requirement includes: 

  • Running SQL Script logic directly on HANA for performance. 
  • Passing dynamic filters (WHERE conditions). 
  • Handling DB errors gracefully. 
  • Returning meaningful messages to the user if data is missing or if invalid filters are passed. 

To meet this, we design: 

  • An AMDP class containing SQL Script logic. 
  • A table function CDS to expose AMDP results at HANA level. (Optional based on architecture) 
  • A simple ABAP report calling the AMDP method and capturing exceptions. 

3.Technical Components 

This solution involves the following SAP artifacts: 

ABAP Objects 

ABAP Class (AMDP) 

  • Name: ZAMDP_EXCEPTION_CLASS_A 
  • Interface: IF_AMDP_MARKER_HDB 
  • Method: GET_DATA 
  • Custom SQL Script exception handling using SIGNAL 

ABAP Report 

  • Name: ZAMDP_EXCEPTIONS_S 
  • Builds WHERE clause 
  • Calls AMDP 
  • Catches CX_AMDP_ERROR 
  • Displays results in AL

4.Application Flow 

  • User runs report ZAMDP_EXCEPTIONS_S. 
  • User enters one or more VBTYP values. 
  • ABAP loops over the select-options and calls AMDP. 
  • AMDP performs: -
  • Record count 
  • Exception handling 
  • Data retrieval 
  • If an exception occurs 
    → ABAP catches CX_AMDP_ERROR 
    → Displays meaningful message 
  • If data exists 
    • → Report prints or displays ALV 

 

5.Key Logic Implementation 

5.1 AMDP Class Definition

CLASS zamdp_exception_class_a DEFINITION PUBLIC. 
PUBLIC SECTION. 
INTERFACES if_amdp_marker_hdb.
TYPES: tt_sales TYPE TABLE OF vbak WITH EMPTY KEY. 
METHODS get_data 
IMPORTING 
VALUE(iv_vbtyp) TYPE vbak-vbtyp DEFAULT '' " default required 
EXPORTING 
VALUE(et_final) TYPE tt_sales 
RAISING 
cx_amdp_error. 
ENDCLASS.

5.2 AMDP Method Implementation (SQL Script) 

CLASS zamdp_exception_class_a IMPLEMENTATION. 
METHOD get_data 
BY DATABASE PROCEDURE 
FOR HDB 
LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT 
OPTIONS READ-ONLY 
USING vbak. 
DECLARE lv_count INTEGER; 
-- Count rows 
SELECT COUNT(*) INTO lv_count 
FROM vbak 
WHERE vbtyp = :iv_vbtyp; 
-- Raise custom exception 
IF :lv_count = 0 THEN 
SIGNAL SQL_ERROR_CODE 10001 
SET MESSAGE_TEXT = 'No data found for given VBTYP'; 
END IF; 
-- Fetch data 
et_final = 
SELECT * 
FROM vbak 
WHERE vbtyp = :iv_vbtyp; 
ENDMETHOD. 
ENDCLASS.

5.3 ABAP Report: Selection Screen 

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
*& Report ZAMDP_EXCEPTIONS_S 
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------* 
REPORT zamdp_exceptions_s. 
TABLES: vbak. 
" Select-options for VBTYP 
SELECT-OPTIONS s_vbtyp FOR vbak-vbtyp.

5.4 AMDP Object and result Table  

DATA obj_amdp TYPE REF TO zamdp_exception_class_a. 
DATA it_final TYPE zamdp_exception_class_a=>tt_sales. 
" Create AMDP instance 
obj_amdp = NEW zamdp_exception_class_a( ).

5.5 Calling AMDP Method with Exception Handling & Displaying Data in ALV 

TRY. 
    CLEAR it_final. 
    LOOP AT s_vbtyp INTO DATA(ls_vbtyp). 
      IF ls_vbtyp-sign = 'I' AND ls_vbtyp-option = 'EQ'. 
        CALL METHOD obj_amdp->get_data 
          EXPORTING 
            iv_vbtyp = ls_vbtyp-low 
          IMPORTING 
            et_final = DATA(lt_data).   "temp table 
        " Append data 
        APPEND LINES OF lt_data TO it_final. 
      ENDIF. 
    ENDLOOP. 
    " If some data exists → Display it 
    IF it_final IS NOT INITIAL. 
      WRITE:/ 'VBELN', 10 'AUART', 20 'VKORG', 30 'VTWEG', 40 'SPART', 
              50 'KUNNR', 60 'ERDAT', 70 'ERNAM', 80 'VBTYP'. 
      LOOP AT it_final INTO DATA(ls_row). 
        WRITE: / ls_row-vbeln, 10 ls_row-auart, 20 ls_row-vkorg, 
                 30 ls_row-vtweg, 40 ls_row-spart, 50 ls_row-kunnr, 
                 60 ls_row-erdat, 70 ls_row-ernam, 80 ls_row-vbtyp. 
      ENDLOOP. 
    ENDIF. 
  CATCH cx_amdp_error INTO DATA(lx_err). 
    " Get HANA error text 
    DATA(lv_text) = lx_err->if_message~get_longtext( ).  
    WRITE:/ lv_text. 
ENDTRY.

6.Sample Output 
6.1 If Exception was Not Raised (Data Retrieval )

6.2 Raising Exception

7.Conclusion 

This technical implementation demonstrates Exception handling in AMDP is essential for building stable, performant HANA-optimized applications. 
A well-structured design connecting CDS + AMDP + ABAP ensures: 

  • Clean separation between data retrieval (AMDP class) and presentation (ABAP report). 
  • Handling exceptions in AMDP and propagating them in ABAP. 
  • Using dynamic filters from select-options in SQL Script. 
  • Cleaner integration between HANA SQL Script and ABAP 
  • Displaying results efficiently in ALV tables. 
  • Providing a robust and user-friendly solution for sales order header analysis. 

This approach can be extended for other database-intensive operations in SAP HANA using ABAP and AMDP.

CLASS zamdp_exception_class_a DEFINITION PUBLIC.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES if_amdp_marker_hdb.
    TYPES: tt_sales TYPE TABLE OF vbak WITH EMPTY KEY.
    METHODS get_data
      IMPORTING
        VALUE(iv_vbtyp) TYPE vbak-vbtyp DEFAULT ''   " default required
      EXPORTING
        VALUE(et_final) TYPE tt_sales
      RAISING
        cx_amdp_error.
ENDCLASS.
CLASS zamdp_exception_class_a IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD get_data
    BY DATABASE PROCEDURE
    FOR HDB
    LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
    OPTIONS READ-ONLY
    USING vbak.
    DECLARE lv_count INTEGER;
    -- Count rows
    SELECT COUNT(*) INTO lv_count
      FROM vbak
      WHERE vbtyp = :iv_vbtyp;
    -- Raise custom exception
    IF :lv_count = 0 THEN
        SIGNAL SQL_ERROR_CODE 10001
          SET MESSAGE_TEXT = 'No data found for given VBTYP';
    END IF;
    -- Fetch data
    et_final =
      SELECT *
      FROM vbak
      WHERE vbtyp = :iv_vbtyp;
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ZAMDP_EXCEPTIONS_S
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
REPORT zamdp_exceptions_s.
TABLES: vbak.
" Select-options for VBTYP
SELECT-OPTIONS s_vbtyp FOR vbak-vbtyp.
" AMDP object and result table
DATA obj_amdp TYPE REF TO zamdp_exception_class_a.
DATA it_final TYPE zamdp_exception_class_a=>tt_sales.
" Create AMDP instance
obj_amdp = NEW zamdp_exception_class_a( ).
TRY.
    CLEAR it_final.
    LOOP AT s_vbtyp INTO DATA(ls_vbtyp).
      IF ls_vbtyp-sign = 'I' AND ls_vbtyp-option = 'EQ'.

        CALL METHOD obj_amdp->get_data
          EXPORTING
            iv_vbtyp = ls_vbtyp-low
          IMPORTING
            et_final = DATA(lt_data).   "temp table
        " Append data
        APPEND LINES OF lt_data TO it_final.
      ENDIF.
    ENDLOOP.
    " If some data exists → Display it
    IF it_final IS NOT INITIAL.
      WRITE:/ 'VBELN', 10 'AUART', 20 'VKORG', 30 'VTWEG', 40 'SPART',
              50 'KUNNR', 60 'ERDAT', 70 'ERNAM', 80 'VBTYP'.
      LOOP AT it_final INTO DATA(ls_row).
        WRITE: / ls_row-vbeln, 10 ls_row-auart, 20 ls_row-vkorg,
                 30 ls_row-vtweg, 40 ls_row-spart, 50 ls_row-kunnr,
                 60 ls_row-erdat, 70 ls_row-ernam, 80 ls_row-vbtyp.

  CATCH cx_amdp_error INTO DATA(lx_err).
    " Get HANA error text
    DATA(lv_text) = lx_err->if_message~get_longtext( ).

ENDTRY.

entry.title: SAP to Collaborate with AWS to bring the SAP BTP ABAP Environment to ARM-Based AWS Graviton
entry.content:
Authors: Steven Jones (AWS), Sonja Liénard (SAP)

The key to SAP’s innovation and adoption success has always been its openness, supporting diverse hardware platforms, networks, and technology ecosystems, while offering flexible deployment options for customers operating in mixed and heterogeneous environments. This principle extends to the ABAP Platform and especially the BTP ABAP Environment, which powers next-generation ABAP Cloud applications and extensions. Beyond this openness, SAP is leveraging innovative technologies like AWS's ARM-based Graviton processors. Today, we are excited to announce the evolution of that partnership:

SAP and AWS will collaborate to bring the SAP BTP ABAP environment to ARM-based AWS Graviton processors.

 

A Longstanding History of Co-Innovation in the Cloud

Since 2008, SAP partnered with AWS to help customers leverage cloud innovations. In 2023, we announced that SAP HANA Cloud runs on AWS Graviton, a custom-built chip by AWS that delivers price, performance, and energy efficiency benefits for cloud workloads. By initially migrating SAP HANA Cloud to AWS Graviton3-based Amazon EC2 instances, SAP has seen up to 30% better compute performance for analytical workloads and lowered its compute carbon footprint by an estimated 45%. Building on these experiences, SAP and AWS have been continuously innovating to further improve the performance of SAP HANA Cloud.

Driving Flexibility and Performance

SAP BTP ABAP environment is the platform as a service offering for ABAP developers. It’s a cloud-optimized ABAP platform based on SAP HANA Cloud that serves as a development and runtime environment for cloud applications.

Initial tests have shown positive results for ABAP on AWS Graviton architectures, demonstrating strong performance and efficiency gains. With the extensive breadth of Amazon EC2 instance families available on ARM, SAP will be able to select the right instance type and size optimized for ABAP workloads and leverage this diverse portfolio for maximum instance flexibility for our customers.

Why ARM and AWS Graviton?

With AWS Graviton3-based instances, SAP experienced up to 35% price-performance improvement for analytics workloads, and a reduction of the compute carbon footprint of SAP HANA Cloud workloads. With AWS Graviton4-based instances, we’ve seen an up to 25% additional performance improvement for analytical and up to 40% additional improvement for transactional workloads compared to AWS Graviton3-based instances.

Now, with the next AWS Graviton5-based Amazon EC2 M9g instances, we’ve observed a 35-60% increase in the performance of our OLTP queries on SAP HANA Cloud in a single generation. Based on the performance improvements demonstrated in SAP HANA Cloud with AWS Graviton processors, SAP is confident the SAP BTP ABAP environment will also leverage AWS Graviton technology to deliver similar benefits.

A Strategic Partnership for Sustainability

This new collaboration continues our shared commitment to sustainability. SAP is a signatory of Amazon’s Climate Pledge and has accelerated its own sustainability commitment to 2030. Our journey with AWS Graviton aligns perfectly with those goals, and we are eager to see what additional improvements in energy efficiency we can realize together in the future.

What’s Next?

Porting the SAP BTP ABAP environment to AWS Graviton involves adapting its cloud-native architecture, including containerized services and runtime components, to ARM. SAP and AWS teams will continue developing, testing, and working on performance optimization pipelines to ensure a seamless experience for customers.

We look forward to sharing more updates on this project and the value it brings in terms of performance, reliability, and sustainability. Stay tuned as we continue this journey together.
